title: 105_hr3170
content: Section 1 introduces a new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code, which deals with gains from constructive ownership transactions. The new section 1260 in the Internal Revenue Code addresses gains from constructive ownership transactions, treating such gains as short-term capital gain if they exceed the net underlying long-term capital gain. Additionally, the capital gain rate applicable is based on the rates that would have applied to the net underlying long-term capital gain. An interest charge may apply on the deferral of gain recognition. The gain under section 1(h) is determined based on the applicable rate for the net underlying long-term capital gain. An interest charge may apply if gain is treated as short-term capital gain, increasing the taxpayer's tax for the year. The taxpayer may be required to pay interest on underpayments of tax for prior taxable years resulting from including gain in gross income ratably during a constructive ownership transaction period. Any amount payable will affect the deduction for interest paid or accrued during the taxable year. Any increase in tax due to this provision cannot be offset by credits allowable under the tax code. The taxpayer may have to pay interest on underpayments of tax from prior years due to gain inclusion in a constructive ownership transaction period. This interest payment affects the deduction for interest in the current taxable year. Any tax increase from this rule cannot be offset by tax credits. Financial position refers to positions in stocks, debt instruments, partnership interests, or investment trust interests. Positions include interests in futures, forward contracts, short sales, or options. The term 'financial position' refers to positions in stocks, debt instruments, partnership interests, or investment trust interests. A 'position' includes interests in futures, forward contracts, short sales, or options. Taxpayers are treated as having entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract or enter into a forward or futures contract for the same or substantially identical property. Taxpayers are considered to have entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract, enter into a forward or futures contract for the same property, or engage in other transactions with similar effects. This does not apply to positions that are marked to market. Taxpayers are considered to have entered into a constructive ownership transaction if they hold a long position under a notional principal contract, enter into a forward or futures contract for the same property, or engage in other transactions with similar effects. This section does not apply to positions that are marked to market. A long position under a notional principal contract involves the right to receive investment yield and the obligation to reimburse any decline in property value. The terms "forward contract" and "related person" are defined in specific sections of the law. The term "net underlying long-term capital gain" in constructive ownership transactions refers to the total capital gain if the financial position was acquired and sold on specific dates, considering only gains and losses from deemed ownership. The net underlying long-term capital gain in constructive ownership transactions is determined based on the specific dates of acquisition and sale, considering only gains and losses from deemed ownership. If clear and convincing evidence is not provided, the amount is treated as zero. Taxpayers can elect to apply a mark-to-market exception, recognizing gain or loss on open constructive ownership transactions at the close of each taxable year. Taxpayers can elect to have a mark-to-market exception apply, recognizing gain or loss on open constructive ownership transactions at the close of each taxable year. Adjustments are made for subsequent realized gains or losses. Any gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction is treated as ordinary income or loss. If a gain or loss is recognized before the close of the taxable year, it will be treated as ordinary income if the transaction would have applied at the close of the year. Any gain or loss from a constructive ownership transaction is treated as ordinary income or loss. An election under this provision can be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for this section. The election for a constructive ownership transaction, once made, applies to the current taxable year and all subsequent years unless revoked with the Secretary's consent. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. The amendments made by this section apply to gain recognized after the date of the enactment of this Act.
